sections.heading: Definition
sections.content: SNR is the ratio of signal power to noise power in a communication system. It measures the quality of the received signal relative to background noise.

sections.heading: Importance
sections.content: Determines receiver sensitivity and signal quality. Higher SNR means clearer, more reliable communication. Critical parameter for system design and performance evaluation. Affects the ability to recover the original modulating signal.

title: SNR Formulas
note: Power SNR = (Voltage SNR)² when measured across the same impedance

title: SNR in Decibels
reasons: Easier to work with large ranges of values

title: II. Noise Factor and Noise Figure

formulas.name: Noise Factor (F)
formulas.description: The ratio of input SNR to output SNR in a device or system. It measures how much noise the device adds.

title: Application in Receiver Quality

sections.heading: Key Points
points: Lower NF = Better receiver - Less noise added by the system
Ideal value: NF = 0 dB (F = 1) - No added noise
Practical values: NF typically ranges from 1-10 dB

note: The first amplifier stage in a receiver chain has the most significant impact on overall system noise figure.

sections.heading: Definition
sections.content: Distortion is any unwanted change in the waveform of a signal as it passes through a system. It represents alterations to the original signal that are not caused by noise.

sections.heading: Common Causes
points: Nonlinearity: Amplifiers or components that don't respond linearly
Frequency response: Unequal amplification across frequencies
Phase distortion: Different frequency components delayed differently
Intermodulation: Multiple signals mixing in nonlinear devices
Harmonic distortion: Creation of harmonic frequencies

title: Distortion vs. Noise
conclusion: Key Difference: Distortion is deterministic and signal-dependent, while noise is random and signal-independent.

sections.heading: Undesirable Distortion
sections.content: Unwanted signal degradation that reduces communication quality:

sections.heading: Desirable Distortion
sections.content: Intentional signal modification for beneficial purposes:
points: Dolby Noise Reduction: Pre-emphasis and de-emphasis to reduce noise
Musical Effects: Overdrive, fuzz, and distortion pedals for creative sound
Audio Enhancement: Bass boost, treble enhancement
Signal Processing: Compression, limiting for broadcast

title: Summary

items.title: Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR)
items.content: Measures signal quality relative to noise; higher values indicate better performance. Can be expressed in voltage, power, or decibels.

items.title: Noise Factor & Figure
items.content: Quantifies noise added by receivers and amplifiers. Lower values indicate better receiver quality and sensitivity.

items.title: Distortion
items.content: Systematic changes to signal waveform. Can be undesirable (degradation) or desirable (intentional enhancement like Dolby or musical effects).

conclusion: Understanding these concepts is essential for designing and evaluating communication systems with optimal performance and signal quality.
